prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: LAB-FIR
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In this science goal, we intend to observe two LABs, B6 and B7, associated with strong FIR sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The LABs, B6 and B7, are very likely powered by the star formation from a group of galaxies, as suggested by the SF-based model (Cen and Zheng 2013). The expected dust continuum fluxes at 240 GHz are predicted from the dust models based on the Herschel data and LABOCA data, and the estimated values are 1.4 mJy for B6 and 2.3 mJy for B7, respectively. We therefore request a sensitivity of 25 microJy/beam at 240 GHz, yielding a signal-to-noise ratio of about 11 for B6 and 18 for B7 if the dust emission comes from five unresovled sources.
With the proposed ALMA observation, the CO line may be detected as a bonus. Thus, we will try to search for CO(7-6) line in two basebands in spectral mode. The narrowband filter, previously discovered the LABs (Palunas et al. 2004), was desgined to search for the redshift of Lyman line in the range 2.356 to 2.401 (dz=0.045). Two ALMA basebands will cover a redshift range of 0.016. The probability to detect the CO(7-6) line emission is about 36%.
Based on a large nearby sample for (ultra)luminous infrared galaxies, Papadopoulos et al. (2012) found a median CO(6-5)/CO(1-0) line ratio of 0.22. Thus, we assume the CO(7-6)/CO(1-0) line ratio to be 0.2 for our sources. Adopting a gas-to-dust mass ratio of 150, dust masses from the dust models, expected line width of 300 km/s, and an ULIRG conversion factor of 1 Msun/(K km/s pc^2), the expected CO(7-6) line fluxes will be 7.4 mJy for B6 and 15 mJy for B7, respectively. An achieved noise level of 0.25 mJy/beam at a velocity resolution of 100 km/s will lead to signal-to-noise ratios of 6 for B6 and 12 for B7, respectively, if the line emission comes from 5 unresolved sources.

The main science goal is to detect continuum, thus two basebands are in continuum mode. Two basebands are set to search for CO(7-6) line. As the line is expected to be weak, the widest spectral resolution of 10 km/s is good enough for our project.
We set a LAS size of 1.5 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of about 13 kpc, and a required angular resolution of about 0.5 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of about 4.2 kpc.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SSA22-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim to detect the dust emission for 10 LABs in the SSA22 field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We primarily aim to detect the dust continuum. Thus, the continuum mode is chosen.

We set a LAS size of 2 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of about 16 kpc. To boost sensitivity, we ask for the compact configuration, providing an angular resolution of about 1.3 arcsec (about 10 kpc on a linear scale).

This project is to search for the dust continuum. Assuming a dust temperature of 40 K (45 K for B6 and 35 K for B7 in J2143-4423), and a dust emissivity index of beta=2, the expected flux for a submm source with an FIR luminosity as ARP220 will be around 0.46 mJy at 262 GHz at a redshift of 3.1. We therefore request a sensitivity of 65 microJy/beam at 262 GHz, yielding a signal-to-noise ratio of 7 for the source like ARP220 at z=3.1.

262 GHz instead of 233 GHz (the standard frequency at band 6 for continuum mode) was chosen for continuum observations as the continuum flux is expected to increase by power law with a spectral index of 3.5 to 4, which will reduce the required observation time for the same SFR detection threshold.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SSA22-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Aim to detect the dust emission for 10 LABs in the SSA22 field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We primarily aim to detect the dust continuum. Thus, the continuum mode is chosen.

We set a LAS size of 2 arcsec, corresponding to a source extent of about 16 kpc. To boost sensitivity, we ask for the compact configuration, providing an angular resolution of about 1.3 arcsec (about 10 kpc on a linear scale).

This project is to search for the dust continuum. Assuming a dust temperature of 40 K (45 K for B6 and 35 K for B7 in J2143-4423), and a dust emissivity index of beta=2, the expected flux for a submm source with an FIR luminosity as ARP220 will be around 0.46 mJy at 262 GHz at a redshift of 3.1. We therefore request a sensitivity of 65 microJy/beam at 262 GHz, yielding a signal-to-noise ratio of 7 for the source like ARP220 at z=3.1.

262 GHz instead of 233 GHz (the standard frequency at band 6 for continuum mode) was chosen for continuum observations as the continuum flux is expected to increase by power law with a spectral index of 3.5 to 4, which will reduce the required observation time for the same SFR detection threshold.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Narrow band imaging is a powerful tool to search for high redshift star-forming galaxies via Lyman alpha emission. With this method, a particular class of objects, known as "Lyman alpha blobs" (LABs), has been identified and characterized by their large physical extent of 30 to 200 kpc. The origin of Lyman alpha emission in LABs is still unclear and under debate. Our deep radio data from ATCA and far-infrared (FIR) archival data from Herschel in protocluster J2143-4423 show that radio and FIR emission is detected in two out of four LABs. These multi-wavelength band data are useful to study the properties of LABs. However, observations with higher angular resolution and sensitivity are definitely needed to reveal the spatial fine structure of the FIR emission and to identify the expected more compact individual galaxy-sized sources whose properties then can be studied in detail. The paucity of detections make the available information very biased and we also need to oberve a large sample. We therefore propose to observe two FIR-detected LABs in J2143-4423 and a large unbiased sample in SSA 22 to study the heating mechanism of LABs and test the star formation (SF)-based model.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
